text: the Obama administration imposed
sanctions on Syrian President Bashar
al-assad and six other officials in the
leadership of that country although the
step was largely symbolic it signified a
shift and perhaps a decisive shift in US
policy towards Syria a country that has
been beset by a two-month uprising over
the authoritarian rule of the asset
family for more than four decades the
timing of the sanctions was interesting
it comes as the Syrian government at
least publicly shows signs of renewed
confidence after staggering just weeks
ago in the face of protests that
stretched across the country Syrian
television has been suffuse with
promises of reform be it changes in
higher education to anti-corruption
campaigns the government has also
undertaken steps of questionable
sincerity and talking with key
dissidents in Damascus who have made
their own demands before a dialogue
begins the sanctions at least suggested
that American officials and perhaps
European officials as well have given up
hope on mr. esset as a reformer American
policy has been hard pressed to navigate
these challenges to navigate the
differences that are foot in so many
countries at the same time but he faces
a region of almost bewilderingly in the
throes of a moment that everyone agrees
is decisive but no one quite yet knows
where it's going to end
